instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Hi Everyone,

Signed up because I have this 3208-B board I cannot work out...



[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]One-wire circuit operates as expected (green then orange light all good).[/FONT][/COLOR]

[FONT=Verdana, Arial, Tahoma, Calibri, Geneva, sans-serif][COLOR=#333333]Fan spins on high, never chimes or posts and of course, no backlight. IMHO, the CPU gets too hot quite quickly...[/COLOR][/FONT]
[FONT=Verdana, Arial, Tahoma, Calibri, Geneva, sans-serif][COLOR=#333333]C.S. not liquid damaged, but the board was really dirty and needed a really good clean. IMHO it was liquid damage from humidity.[/COLOR][/FONT]


[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]On R7402; Pin 2 == 8.4v and R7402 Pin 1 == 340mV. [/FONT][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]The resistance of R7402 == 91.3k and should be 90.9k, so it's right which makes me reluctant to replace it...
I changed R7402 just to test and get the same measurements.[/FONT][/COLOR]

[FONT=Verdana, Arial, Tahoma, Calibri, Geneva, sans-serif][COLOR=#333333]Another interesting issue is that when I measure[/COLOR][/FONT][COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana] Probe 152, Pin 1 on U6990, it causes the fan to slow down to about half speed. Then it builds its way back up again.[/FONT][/COLOR]


Does anyone have any suggestions?

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: Check bios area maybe corrosion maybe missing resistor....

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Thanks, I will check it closer in the morning.
The board is very very clean though. There was no corrosion evident anywhere.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Definitely can't see any corrosion or any missing components.

Can someone suggest some measurements to take so I can start tracing it please?


Just to reiterate;
R7402 is giving me 340mV on pin1 and 8.4v on pin 2

The fan slows to almost a stop then builds back up again if I measure Probe 152 near U6990.

C6994 gives 7.2v on pin 1, and 3.4v on pin 2.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
No need to measure anything around U6990, you have a green light so 3V42 must be ok.
Do you actually have CPU Vcore on L7510? If yes continue with the next: 
I have had a few of these boards with no apparent damage and they usually have PCH problems. Heat up the PCH area and see if it works again after, not reflow just 150C or so.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 5820"]
Do you actually have CPU Vcore on L7510? If yes continue with the next:
[/quote]
I get steady 1.125v

[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 5820"]
I have had a few of these boards with no apparent damage and they usually have PCH problems. Heat up the PCH area and see if it works again after, not reflow just 150C or so.[/QUOTE]

Heating it didn't seem to make any difference.

When I plug in power the fan doesn't do the little start-stop-start-stop sequence the Airs usually do. It just spins for a while, then starts to speed up.

Thanks for your suggestions.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: Any further suggestions?

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Bump.
Still trying to find some direction on this board. :)

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Only thing I can suggest for now is to reprogram the BIOS. Save the original file first!

[url]https://drive.google.com/file/d/0ByfhQ_x0v-tZSlJCaFRJenFoX1U/view?usp=sharing[/url]

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: Thanks, I'll do it today.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Just getting back onto this board today;

Does this look right? pp1v5_s3rs0 1.v35
pp1v5_s0 1v06
I was expecting 1v5 on each of those lines.

Board was working, we changed the SSD, and bang, no boot.


pp1v5_s0 is giving me 1v5 now, but pp1v5_s3rs0 is still giving me 1.3

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: Measure voltages on Q7801, R7850 still ok?

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
I checked a working board and the output is really 1.5V. Gate voltage on Q7801 is 5.4V to turn it on. So you either have a dead Q7801 or a very heavy load on 1.5V_S3 pulling it down.
Check for low resistance to GND on 1.5V_S3RS0, if that is ok I suspect a dead Q7801.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Out of interest, how would I find a heavy load?
(A document or YouTube clip if you know of one would do.)

I need to order a Q7801 so may as well keep learning while I wait for it to arrive.

Thanks.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: You measure resistance to GND on that bus, if it seems very low there is something wrong.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6181"]I checked a working board and the output is really 1.5V. Gate voltage on Q7801 is 5.4V to turn it on. So you either have a dead Q7801 or a very heavy load on 1.5V_S3 pulling it down.
Check for low resistance to GND on 1.5V_S3RS0, if that is ok I suspect a dead Q7801.[/QUOTE]


Resistance to ground from R7954 (PP1v5_S3RS0) is 270ohms. Is this right, I am not sure what I should be expecting.
From Probe 587 is 299ohms.
From R7850 is 295ohms.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: That seems fine to me. Don't you have a donor 2936 or 3115 board? Q7801 is on both of them.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: I have a 3115, but it looks like a different chip. It's a fair bit larger.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: RJK03E0DNS seems like a fitting replacement to me.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Q7261 on the 3115 is a good 50% larger; I don't think the terminals will reach.

Will try and report back shortly.

threads.title: MacBook Air 820-3208 Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: Hmmm, it must of course be physically the same size. Go over the 3115 board to see if any FETs are the same size, then check if it is an N-channel. It is not a critical part, it acts only as a switch.
